page.title: 01COLN VALLEY :INTRODUCTION
page.content: This area is part of the Cotswold region which consists of an undulating tableland with winding streams which have cut deep into the land. The wolds are windswept and exposed with few houses to be seen. Fields are divided by walls of loose stone, and excellent crops of wheat and barley are grown. Every 5 years the crops are discontinued and the fields used for sheep pasture. Down in the Coln valley are rich water meadows and grazing for sheep and cattle. The picturesque villages sheltering here are built from the local oolitic limestone which mellows naturally and whose roofs become covered with lichen and moss. The whole district is a conservation area and attracts a large number of tourists. The main villages are Coln Rogers, Winson and Ablington.
